questions.question: What percentage of acne patients have gut dysbiosis?
questions.explanation: Studies show approximately 54% of acne patients have altered gut flora (dysbiosis). This highlights the importance of addressing gut health alongside topical treatments for acne.

questions.question: What is the 'atopic march'?
options: A type of exercise for skin health
The progression from eczema → food allergies → asthma → allergic rhinitis
A treatment protocol for skin conditions
questions.explanation: The atopic march describes the typical progression of atopic conditions: eczema (usually in infancy) → food allergies → asthma → allergic rhinitis. Addressing gut health early can interrupt this progression.

questions.question: What percentage of rosacea patients test positive for SIBO?
questions.explanation: Up to 46% of rosacea patients test positive for SIBO—13 times higher than controls. In studies, treating SIBO led to complete or near-complete clearing of rosacea in over 90% of SIBO-positive patients.

questions.question: Why is dairy often problematic for acne?
options: It increases IGF-1 which promotes sebum production
It has too much vitamin D
questions.explanation: Dairy increases IGF-1 (insulin-like growth factor), which promotes sebum production and skin cell proliferation. Whey protein is especially problematic. This is why dairy elimination is often the first step in gut-based acne protocols.

questions.question: Psoriasis patients have how many times higher rates of celiac disease than the general population?
questions.explanation: Psoriasis patients have 2-3 times higher rates of celiac disease than the general population. Additionally, many have gluten antibodies without full celiac. A gluten-free trial often significantly improves psoriasis.

questions.question: Which nutrients support DAO enzyme function for histamine clearance?
options: Vitamin B6, copper, and vitamin C
questions.explanation: Vitamin B6, copper, and vitamin C are key cofactors for DAO (diamine oxidase) enzyme function. DAO breaks down histamine from food in the gut. Supporting these nutrients helps reduce histamine-related skin symptoms.

questions.question: How long does skin improvement typically take after addressing gut issues?
questions.explanation: Skin improvement typically takes 4-12 weeks after gut issues are addressed. Skin cells turn over slowly, so internal changes take time to manifest externally. Setting this expectation early prevents discouragement.

questions.question: What happens when the skin becomes a 'backup elimination route'?
options: Toxins exit through pores causing eruptions and inflammation
questions.explanation: When the liver and gut elimination pathways are overwhelmed (constipation, impaired detox, high toxin load), the body uses skin as a secondary elimination route. Toxins exit through pores, causing eruptions, rashes, and inflammation.

questions.question: What are common high-histamine foods to avoid for skin reactions?
options: Aged cheeses, wine, fermented foods, canned fish
questions.explanation: High-histamine foods include: aged cheeses, wine, beer, fermented foods (sauerkraut, kombucha, kimchi), cured/smoked meats, vinegar, and canned or leftover fish/meat. Fresh foods are generally lower in histamine.

questions.question: Which probiotic strain has evidence for helping eczema?
questions.explanation: Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG (LGG) has research evidence supporting its benefit for eczema, particularly in children. Studies show it can help prevent and reduce severity of atopic dermatitis, especially when given early.
